title: Comparatives and Superlatives
description: Learn how to compare things using comparative and superlative adjectives.

rules.title: Comparative Adjectives - Short Adjectives
rules.explanation: For short adjectives (1-2 syllables), add -er to compare two things. Use 'than' after the comparative.
spelling_rules: Double consonant after short vowel: hot → hotter, big → bigger
Change y to i: dry → drier, sunny → sunnier

examples.sentence: The weather is drier in autumn.

rules.title: Comparative Adjectives - Long Adjectives
rules.explanation: For longer adjectives (3+ syllables), use 'more' before the adjective.

examples.sentence: Summer is more humid than winter.
This forecast is more accurate than that one.
Spring weather is more comfortable than summer.

rules.title: Superlative Adjectives
rules.explanation: Use superlatives to compare one thing with all others in a group. Use 'the' before superlatives.

examples.sentence: January is the coldest month in Korea.
This is the most beautiful season.

rules.title: Irregular Comparatives and Superlatives
rules.explanation: Some adjectives have irregular comparative and superlative forms.

examples.sentence: The weather is better today than yesterday.
This is the worst storm of the year.
Today is the best day for a picnic.

rules.title: As...as for Equal Comparison
rules.explanation: Use 'as + adjective + as' to say two things are the same, or 'not as...as' to say they are different.

examples.sentence: Today is as warm as yesterday.
Spring is not as hot as summer.
This winter is as cold as last year.

exercises.question: August is _____ month of the year.
The weather today is _____ (good) than yesterday.
This is _____ storm I've ever seen.
Autumn weather is _____ (comfortable) than summer weather.
Spring is the _____ (beautiful) season in Korea.
Which is correct?
options: This is more easy than that.
This is more easier than that.
